body_html: Yes, but if you read the readme, you can see that I save a set of weights first, and then load it into both models (i.e. the weights are exactly the same). Also, you can have a look at the "trace" outputs in the logs/ directory; though not the whole data of the arrays are shown (default numpy clipping), you can get a taste of how the numbers change.
body_text: Yes, but if you read the readme, you can see that I save a set of weights first, and then load it into both models (i.e. the weights are exactly the same). Also, you can have a look at the "trace" outputs in the logs/ directory; though not the whole data of the arrays are shown (default numpy clipping), you can get a taste of how the numbers change.
body: Yes, but if you read the readme, you can see that I save a set of weights first, and then load it into both models (i.e. the weights are **exactly the same**). Also, you can have a look at the "trace" outputs in the logs/ directory; though not the whole data of the arrays are shown (default numpy clipping), you can get a taste of how the numbers change.
